discourse_list.title: Decentralized voter committees: Wednesday and Thursday 9pm CEST - getting real edition

content.content: Decentralized Voter Committees I think most of us are probably hurting over the massive crash of crypto prices and the financial damage it is causing. But we must take control of that energy and direct it towards evolving Maker with actions that can fix our flaws and improve growth, income and resilience. This week of voter committee zoom calls will be very important to attend, as things are starting to get real and I will. Both weekly calls will from now on move to 9pm CEST, and continue weekly at this time.  Wednesday 9pm CEST - Join Link  The Wednesday 9 pm CEST call will, as usual for Wednesday calls, focus on the short term task of establishing the voter committee format as the one-stop shop of active MKR holder interaction with the maker governance process, by leading through example and creating precedents that will incentivize the decentralized workforce to properly follow the will of MKR holders. Wednesday this week I will present a plan on how to change the current priorities of the core units through MKR voting, redirecting them towards the list of Focus Objectives I have been publishing for the last few months. We will also once again discuss the list of Focus Objectives, including what to add, remove or rearrange. Since I am now pushing for their immediate enforcement there may be greater engagement than in the past and we may have an opportunity for a healthy discussion about how to prioritize. We must also begin the process of reducing budgets for certain core units, in order to rein in spending as we are headed into an uncertain period and a bear market of unknown length. The goal is also to serve as an important example of how MKR voter signaling can influence governance and set the precedent that public voter committee calls is the primary place where high level decision making occurs. A reminder: the focus of the wednesday call will not be on implementation of the endgame plan. The Wednesday DVC calls will not assume the endgame plan is going to pass. It will be about making changes and optimizations that are relevant no matter what the long term vision is, including fixing budgets and prioritizations and keep scope creep and power creep in check. This is congruent with the endgame plan, since its first step is to define the core of maker and remove anything that detracts from it - but taking such action will be useful whether or not the rest of the endgame plan is implemented.  Thursday 9pm CEST - Join Link  Thursday this week I will present part 4 of the endgame plan: Understanding MetaDAOs, which is a deep dive on metadaos that highlights their key, “baked-in” synergies with maker, and provides a lot of examples of hypothetical metaDAOs. The baked in maker synergies includes the 3 classes of metaDAOs: Creator, Governor and Reformer, and the 3 MetaDAO core products: MetaDAO Lending Engine (D3M powered), Decentralized Vault Frontend (stability fee revenue share) and Decentralized Workforce Results Guarantee (budget overhead fee) The MetaDAO examples will focus both on the metaverse and meme warfare aspect of MetaDAOs with highly hypothetical examples of what MetaDAOs could look like in the long run (although in practice they will likely still look quite different as it cannot be predicted). This includes examples like DogeDAO The other group of examples will be practical attempts at early stage “clustering”, meaning identifying opportunities where products, resources and counterparties have potential for synergy if connected to a MetaDAO. This includes in particular M0, the “low risk high reward” metaDAO that will attempt to validate the Endgame Plan and MetaDAO paradigm, as well as other metadaos concepts that focus on ecosystem collaboration and partnerships such as with aave and polygon or optimism and the synthetix ecosystem. I will reach out to relevant core units in advance and ask them to make sure they are represented on the calls.  Wednesday Call Link Thursday Call Link   Recordings

Not gonna lie. That was the most decentralized I’ve ever seen 1 person talk for > 2 hours Certainly didn’t make me with my ~12 MKR want to talk. Perhaps we can have more specifics, less blaming the delegates you yourself empowered, and less asking people to kiss the ring. Just a thought
Can someone paste the chat log into the forum?
Rob:  Not gonna lie. That was the most decentralized I’ve ever seen 1 person talk for > 2 hours   Lol, wut? Is there a recording?
Welcome to the party…that same guy will yabber on until someone passes out, dies, or both. I skip these things because I’d rather pick lint out of a belly button (and not even my own belly button!).

The recording should be posted shortly. I have been presenting the Endgame plan transparently and openly for months, getting a lot of feedback and making many significant changes based on that feedback. It is an incredibly powerful and ambitious plan that, if executed, will take Maker to a new standard of decentralization, resilience, above-board governance and viral growth. I have held voter committees for several weeks now to begin the process of formally organizing governance to occur in public, and as I explained last week, there is currently no major competing proposal with publicly committed MKR backing it, which is why it’s time for me to take action. You can’t simply wish for things to be decentralized and functional - building a DAO unfortunately isn’t that easy. It has to be carefully engineered into existence, and this is incredibly hard work. Most people would probably consider it impossible knowing all the pitfalls, risks and challenges, and I’m one of the few people that both believe it to be possible without having to compromise on decentralization and am speaking from enough experience to not just be falling victim to the dunning kruger effect. If you disagree with my general direction and the potential of the Endgame Plan and MetaDAOs - then you should organize against it by trying to develop your own competing direction and set of proposals. Or simply organize to support the status quo. Just please do it in public as soon as you start to involve core units or paid delegates - the only type of governance action that is unambiguously harmful is hidden power brokering with the decentralized workforce, as it is the antithesis of accessible and transparent governance and creates harmful conflict of interest. If you want to collaborate and improve the Endgame Plan even further, then at this point it should be clear that I’m highly receptive of constructive criticism and feedback, and as mentioned above many features of the plan are the result of iterative feedback during the early stages of the calls.

Man, do what you gotta do. But the title of the meeting suggested it would be 1) decentralized, 2) have actual voters who weren’t you talking, 3) a committee of more than 1 person. “One guy tricking 65 people to show up for 2 and a half hours” would be more accurate. That was probably 10 thousand dai in labor expenses sucked into that meeting, which could have just been a long memo. I think I speak for everyone that it was downright embarrassing how you talked over people and demanded kow towing. Just take a CEO title or appoint specific representatives for your interests and be done with it. It was incredibly uncomfortable listening to the delegates forced to suck up to you and the facilitators you asked to be there and then not let them say their piece in a detailed way. I hope you watch the recording in case you don’t realize how cringe a lot of that was. I’ll skip the rest of these. Good luck and all that Edited to add: Really glad I wrote this because a lot of DMs are thanking me. Guess this is why it’s important to have someone whose paycheck can’t be cut off to say these things

Instead of repeatedly insulting me you should just post your own superior alternative and gather support for it. You can make your own decentralized voter committee, having multiple voices in governance is exactly what we need. It’s literally just a public call that any MKR holder can create, it requires no special governance rights or process - that’s what makes it decentralized. You chose to join it out of your own free will, if you hated it so much you should have just left?  appoint specific representatives for your interests  If this is what you want me to do then I don’t understand why you are so unhappy with the meeting, since that is in general the point of the DVCs, but particularly today I think I made it clear how exactly that can be done in practice, by attending and delegating towards clearly defined DVC parties. We need Maker Governance to serve the interest of MKR holders, and for that to happen voters need to make it very clear what exactly they want (complaining vaguely isn’t enough), and what they are going to do for that to happen (e.g. delegation). It’s a process of publicly organizing and formalizing the different points of view, so that delegates can understand, follow and extrapolate from these views, in order to make governance actually operate in the interest of MKR holders, rather than just be a self-referential bureaucracy.

Rune, I’d like to chime in to share a bit of that frustration. Being a DAO creates quite a bit of regulatory and legal risk, while also making things like the real world assets staff lift a boulder with both hands tied behind their back due to no legal structure. If you’re just going to be a dictator with your 80000 tokens, why not drop the DAO charade before some government comes after us? The frustration isn’t that you don’t have a right to push your own agenda. It’s that you do it while also handicapping the organization’s ability to operate and massive legal exposure. Perhaps you should just reincorporate Maker if you don’t want it to be decentralized. It would probably run better. But you’re making recorded calls saying you’re going to ram through your own agenda, which will certainly be used as evidence of fake decentralization. Is this a decentralized, inefficient, frustrating, lightly regulated DAO? Or is this a corporate structure responsible for all the traditional taxes and liability and compliance under the founder? It really can’t be both
I like your plan, but nobody realistically has the power to oppose you. It’s fine if you want to take over, but using terms like “voters” and “different points of view” does feel misleading.

I think we are all in agreement that we must do something to get to a point where there isn’t a single person that controls the majority of active voting power. Where I disagree is that sticking our heads in the sand should somehow solve the problem, that’s why I’m taking action with a plan that will actually change that. However pretending that 8% of the circulating supply somehow implies dictatorship is completely mistaken. There is absolutely nothing preventing multiple large token holders, or a larger group of small token holders, from organizing to push some different direction, if they wanted to. I have repeatedly been encouraging this for months, and I have telegraphed my own actions the entire time. At this point inaction means consent. And if my assumption of consent turns out to not be the case, great! Mission accomplished, we will see more active voting as MKR holders organize to oppose me and the fledgling Endgame Party. If that doesn’t happen, then that’s also great. I will deliver to all of you, for free, a powerful plan that condenses my experiences from working on maker for the past 7 years, that I have been spending more than a year researching and preparing, and that will quickly result in total and irreversible decentralization of maker governance, solve voter apathy, enforce separation of powers, prevent scope creep and supercharge the project with viral growth. And then I will never have to engage in hands on governance drama ever again. Literally all I ever wanted was to simply be able to sit back, delegate my MKR, and count on the DAO to run itself sustainably. This is my final attempt at trying to get us there.

rune:  Literally all I ever wanted was to simply be able to sit back, delegate my MKR, and count on the DAO to run itself sustainably   I feel like you could have had this, but chose to support delegates that constantly miss votes (Monet), always abstain (Gauntlet), change their mind frequently (Flip Flap Flop), or avoid ever being a swing vote (Feedblack Loops). I think they’re many of them abrasive and wrong, but you have a lot of delegates who are at least well informed and have clear ideas that you’ve generally ignored

Literally all I ever wanted was to simply be able to sit back, delegate my MKR, and count on the DAO to run itself sustainably.  If that’s what you want, you should hire one delegate who really understands your viewpoints and delegate everything to him. Then you can get regular updates and closely communicate with him to make sure things stay on track. Adding more people ensures you are going to have to spend a lot of time managing people.

You might be right, and if I had just picked “the right” delegates perhaps things would have turned out for the better for a time. But in the end it wouldn’t be a decentralized equilibrium because it would rely on some specific individuals to act “correctly”. It may seem decentralized in the short run, but eventually people will change jobs, change their minds, get hacked, or whatever. We need the entire structure to enforce decentralization to the highest degree that is possible without compromising efficiency at scale, and it must work even assuming things like a corrupt or negligent majority of actors involved, and only very minimal semi-altruism from MKR holders and true believers in the DAO.

What needs to happen is that the incentivized delegates and the incentivized MKR holder DVC participants (if we manage to implement that) will learn from me and each other over time, and be able to continue the path towards the Endgame and irreversible decentralization, without me needing to be involved once the snowball has started to roll by itself.

Incentivized workers still often still be lazy or do dumb things. You will always have to pay attention to whoever you are delegating your Maker to make sure they are doing their job correctly. That’s especially true if you control most of the Maker used in governance.
rune:  But in the end it wouldn’t be a decentralized equilibrium because it would rely on some specific individuals to act “correctly”.   Inversebrah

Yes, that’s why we need a plan that is going to make voting actually decentralized. That’s the root problem we need to solve, and we cannot get around the “incentivized and lazy”, because that is the reality we will live in once we do incentivized voting (which is the only way we can count on to deal with voter apathy. It is now proven that praying and begging doens’t work). That’s why we need the Endgame Plan so we get strong checks and balances including voter committees, clearly defined, finite scope and multi-strategy delegates so voters can easily choose the values they believe in, and many other critical features

rune:  voter committees   But… no voters appear to show up to these? Meeoh came to a few and that one guy with 4k came like twice. It’s not a voter committee if there’s no voters, and you say anyone paid by the protocol doesn’t count.

Ippy:  that constantly miss votes (Monet)   Just piping in because I’m reading this thread now but, I’ve been voting each week  Have been delayed in sharing vote reasoning, which I plan to rectify soon but personally I feel this is somewhat counterbalanced by the fact this lower’s the DAO’s delegate costs. That being said there are a lot of great delegate options that have joined recently who i’d love to see get more support. And I’m unable to attend yesterday or today’s meetings so who knows maybe these votes will be reallocated elsewhere. Sorry for taking this thread off topic for a sec but just wanted to extricate myself from the oncoming bus I’m being thrown under

It’s a legit decentralized voter committee if just a single independent MKR holder shows up, meaning not paid by the protocol and not a counterparty that is doing business with the protocol. As long as there is just a single person that is there purely from their incentive as an MKR holder, then they can act as the sanity check on the decentralized workforce including delegates, supporting core units, etc. If it’s simply me interacting with the delegates, core units etc, then it still works. I’m providing the MKR holder perspective, and any other MKR holders can watch the videos to see if I uncover something that stands out, or if misrepresenting their views. Even if I was just a small scale grassroots community member, as long as we were already ossified in a properly balanced endgame state it would still work because the large whales would be able to review the recordings and would react if some kind of conflict of interest scandal, metadao penalty case etc came up.

I’m just saying the obvious lack of decentralization is going to get a lot of people here sued, hit with tax bills, or something else. Blatantly saying you’re just gonna do it your way and forcefully destroys whatever protections decentralization provides, but we still get stuck with all the bad parts of it. This isn’t about the substance of what you’re proposing or whether you have the right to do it. It’s that you’re rugging the “DAO” part of Maker again
It would be way easier to just hire someone to represent your interests than rely on random pure Maker holders showing up to committee meetings.
Can you be specific? Pointing to vague threats due to lack of decentralization is not helpful. If the concern is lawsuits and taxes, caselaw or legal guidances would be very helpful here.

I do not understand why this project is bad-mouthed, it provides a platform where everyone can exchange ideas, especially as a small MKR Hodler, you can contribute to the MKR success. With MetaDaos the decentralized aspect is further promoted because these groups communities and DAOS function self-sufficiently. Especially the MetaDaos have the potential to let the whole thing here become something bigger, and Rune becomes even more insignificant. MetaDaos can work in all directions and take advantage of the foundation of MKR and funding small group communities or RWA groups in every country on earth, there are so many possibilities.
Taking steps to actually fix voter apathy and broken governance = “rugging the DAO part”… okay sure.

rune:  Taking steps to actually fix voter apathy and broken governance   I’m sympathetic to what you’re attempting to address, but no one is gonna bother if you’re constantly saying “my 80+ thousand MKR is going to do THIS” If anyone was bad enough at math to think their vote counted before, they just got disabused of that notion. Look, I don’t have some magic plan to get people to show up. And Maker would probably be a more reliable employer and business partner with just one person setting a direction. But that’s not a DAO. I hope you talked to a lawyer about this before making it obvious this would just be an unincorporated company
So instead I should let you decide who I’m allowed to delegate my MKR to?

rune:  I should let you decide who I’m allowed to delegate my MKR to?   Man, I don’t know. But if it’s just 1 guy determining everything, maybe put an LLC or something around this thing and stop putting DAO in the name
I’m sure you aren’t being serious, as that obviously isn’t possible. What IS possible is to implement voter incentives, checks and balances, separation of powers, voter committees etc.

So real talk: you come in here regularly with huge, disruptive proposals. They never get implemented and rarely even voted upon. Maybe game theory isn’t your jam, and shouldn’t be the justification for this? This is a really tough problem to solve. Modern democracies struggle with it, as do major corporations. It’s ok to be frustrated, but don’t go from “this works badly” to just breaking the thing you helped build
Go ahead and show me how you would do it better

This discussion leads nowhere, there is no point in complaining but to work on concrete points and offer realistic solutions. It is paraphrased in general and nothing concrete is talked about. Im looking forward for the next voter commitee.
rune:  Go ahead and show me how you would do it better   Back in 10 minutes

While your intent is clearly to better decentralize Maker, your large voting and personality presence also generate significant centralizing forces. Here is an analogy:  given your 80K tokens and willingness to vote them, you are creating a strong gravity field that pulls many smaller players into your orbit.  Some folks are playing up to you and seeking your favor and telling you what you want to hear, as its economically rationale for them to do so.  I think most folks would call this part of the process centralizing

Whatever voting power I have now is voting power I’ve always had. The main difference is that I’m using it to improve decentralization of governance, with full transparency and community input, in a slow and measured attempt to reach community consensus (with the people that share the same principles as me) - as all MKR holders should. So it really makes no sense to claim that it is “centralizing” compared to the status quo.

rune:  Go ahead and show me how you would do it better    Decentralization: You have 80k? Make 16 stacks of 5k. Put them in delegate contracts that you can’t pull from for 6 months. Maybe some delegates are people, some are teams, some are their own DAOs that vote on how their contract votes. I dunno. But spread it around to people you think aren’t going to burn the house down, and then tie your hands so you can’t remove it for a fixed term. Budget: Get rid of Events CU. Don’t need parties. Get rid of Immunefi CU. Just pay the bug bounty program and ditch the $10k/month personnel cost. Get rid of Strategic Happiness CU. Find a part time job for Burban in Growth and let him hand out his swag. Get rid of Deco CU. The terms are bad, it’s a company with its own product. Fund it to get equity or give a grant, but the budget + revenue share is abusive. If it’s important, fund it smartly. Get rid of GovComms. Merge it with GovAlpha, who can help them focus on their job and stop struggling with the operational problems. Bonds: Do what you’re planning already. Publicly traded debt is already professionally underwritten, and has higher yields than what we’re getting on crypto assets. This is the way. Real world assets: Do what you’re planning already. Focus on finishing what we started, and stop bringing in exotic things we can’t manage well. This is the way. Burn/Paying MKR Holders: Do the burn. Do it slow. Do it constantly. Turn it off if profits are less than 5% of market cap. Growing revenues: Bonds, get L2 done, find cheaper oracles that are fine for mid cap tokens with small debt ceiling Like, most of this is just making unpopular decisions and breaking the logjam, which is what you want to do. The problem arises from you wanting to wave a giant flag to every regulator and tax agency in the world that this is not even pretending to be decentralized.
Ippy:  Put them in delegate contracts that you can’t pull from for 6 months   That’s… actually a really good idea. Like electing them for terms. Can still fire them later

Well, this is some great input so thanks for that. I always greatly appreciate specific input on the hard questions. But ultimately we need to also address the hardest question of all, which is the core problem of governance alongside these more immediate fixes, or we will just run into another list of fixes that need to be dealt with in the future. Finally I want to make the comment that regulators really dgaf about what you pretend, they only look at the reality of the situation. I don’t agree that the status quo, or any action I can take based on the status quo, is centralized (will explain below why that’s the same thing). Voting is easily available and I don’t have even close to a majority of circulating supply. If I did something other voters disagreed with and wanted to stop, they would simply do so. On top of that ESM is available so profitable, extractive governance attacks are impossible regardless of how much voting power gets concentrated etc. But even if it was centralized, we would be better off in the eyes of a regulator if we are showing concrete steps to deal with it, vs head in the sand decentralization theater, because again they truly don’t care about that, they might even consider it dishonest. Which again, I don’t believe is currently the case, but if you argue that any steps I can take as a voter are “centralized” then that is equivalent to saying the status quo is centralized. If you have a decentralized state and a single actor can then “un-decentralize” it, then it isn’t decentralized in the first place.

As long as there is ultimately just one guy controlling the majority of the actual votes, then all these committees and checks don’t matter. Really, the decentralizing thing would be to sell off your Maker or stop voting, but that would be terrible for the protocol because it needs a centralized leader to fix things.
I agree regarding budgets. Things like events and swag are nice for a centralized corporation, but decentralized groups need the minimum possible complexity and can’t afford the cognitive loads.

Just to be clear, the committees and checks aren’t about trying to make very low voter turnout sustainable, because it never will be. It is about making voter incentives safe. Once we have the checks and balances in place, we can more safely open the floodgates of voting that will happen once you get paid to do it.
Fully agreed in this crypto market horror show Maker needs to survive - and adjust budgets down accordingly.  Each CU needs to create a budget that adapts to the new reality

I don’t even view it as a budget issue. Decentralized governance is by nature slow and inefficient, so we need to do as few things as possible and those things need to be simple to govern. Marketing and events are complex and difficult to monitor. They need careful control to avoid wasting large amounts of money. Not compatible with Maker’s structure.

I feel this criticism isn’t justified. @rune is presenting an ambitious plan with a lot of details. That takes some time to communicate. Also, apart from @MakerMan and @PaperImperium very few have ever posted well-thought-through proposals of where Maker should go, and it’s in urgent need of direction. Rune managed to galvanize large parts of the active community through a combination of massive MKR holdings, his status as a co-founder and his personality. Yes, that might be “unfair” advantages and give his proposal more limelight than those of other players, but such is the nature of human affairs. Power laws are everywhere. From my perspective as a rather new, and very small delegate (The only person delegating to Flipside is my personal account, at the moment) I applaud the MetaDAO idea, because it would allow me to concentrate on issues and actually build up the in-depth knowledge there to make really good decisions. This can never happen in MakerDAO as a whole, because I can’t ever become good at deciding about RWA vaults, Risk parameters, Governance structures, D3M parameters, PSM mechanics, Crypto collateral and more… It just can’t be done. But I have to vote on everything, or get penalized. This leads to sub-optimal information and sub-optimal decisions. I have yet to see another plan that preservers much of the incredible talent we have working on Maker and allows a much easier to grasp, well-defined structure. Some argue that the complexity rises, but I actually don’t see it that way. MetaDAOs can try and fail safely, while the core business just gets meaner and leaner. This is the way. It also makes the whole ship much easier to understand. Interested in RWA: work on that MetaDAO. Want to set risk parameters: Lurk in Core Forums. Etc… Delegates should ideally not have to deal with everything, but develop strong specializations, and integrate with other specialized delegates in “parties” like the Hawks and Doves in Rune’s presentation. I disagree with incentivizing voter participation. The catalog of possible failure modes is exhaustive: sibyll attacks if we introduce caps, financialization and profit-seeking if we don’t, bribing economies if we introduce voted escrow models, prisoner’s dilemma, likelihood of ever-increasing incentives because these proposals will be most voted on, etc… Voter apathy is a fact. It’s a fact in modern democracies, whose decisions affect everyone in their daily lives. It’s even more of a fact for DeFi protocols where token holders simply want to sit back, dgaf and rake in earnings. One possibility to address that is to introduce a second governance token that you can earn through actively using Maker products, and participating in governance, for instance. Something along the lines of how gaming guilds decorate their top members. @MakerMan has a wonderful proposal on his delegate platform that would allow DAI LP holders governing rights. Awesome! MakerMan delegate platform - Governance / Delegates - The Maker Forum (makerdao.com) These holders use DAI actively and are knowledgable, informed customers. Anyway, I’m happy for this discussion. Maker is the #1 DAO. All other DAOs will have similar problems in a couple of years, while Maker will remain lightyears ahead. Onwards.
Here’s an idea…DELEGATE TO IPPY. I am onboard with the suggestions – especially offboarding teams with “abusive” revenue splits in place – as outlined above.
